Fingerprint evidence, as it is now, is complete junk. The matches are made by human eye, leading to an incredibly large amount of false matches (1 in 18 or 1 in 30 depending on your study, neither is a good number) (http://theconversation.com/fingerprinting-to-solve-crimes-not-as-robust-as-you-think-85534). It is totally possible to have your fingerprints matched to another person as happened in 2004 linking the wrong person (a person who had never been out of the states) to a terrorist bombing in Spain (https://oig.justice.gov/special/s0601/exec.pdf). The attorney from Oregon spent 4 days in jail as the FBI went along on the false conclusion his fingerprints matched that of a man from Algeria. Literally the terrible science used by investigators could get you detained for something that happened on the other side of the world. That is not the only case of this happening, but is perhaps the most high profile. THERE IS ONLY ONE SOLID SCIENTIFIC PIECE OF FORENSIC EVIDENCE AND THAT IS DNA, EVERYTHING ELSE SHOULD CAUSE ANY REASONABLE PERSON SOME REASONABLE DOUBT AND A REQUIRED NOT GUILTY VERDICT.

Actual scene investigator here. My concern is the "CSI effect" getting worse - this is the expectation in jurors now that crime scenes will be laden with trace evidence, when the reality is far from that. Considering that even common techniques like fingerprinting are flawed and give incorrect answers more often than we think, how can we be sure these be techniques are going to be reliable enough to be useful? To be admissible in Court, a technique has to be proven to be scientifically valid and reliable, so even if one of these was perfect, it's a long way until we see them used - and longer still before we'll know we can trust the results.

Also, I've seen a dog pick up a trace of accelerant (fuel used to start a fire) from a few tens of metres when our electronic sensor might not have detected it from a couple of centimetres, so we've got a long way to go on the "electronic noses", though some exist already.

I'd say that the future forensic technology with the biggest impact would be to give judges a proper math education.
Too many times people have been sentenced based on a judges misunderstanding of probability.
The classic case is Sally Clark who was convicted of smothering her two children on the reasoning that "The probability that both the children smothered themselves in their sleep is so extremely low that she must have done it". They failed to take into account the probability of a mother killing her children, which was actually an even lower probability. If they had just been educated in Bayesian probability this would not have happened. Bayesian statistics could even be used to come up with an estimate for the actual probability of a person being guilty, meaning we could move away from "The judges and jury's gut feeling/biases" and put a limit on what's an acceptable fail rate. 99.9%? That would mean 1 of every 1000 convicts are not guilty.
That's very likely to be better than what we have today, but it becomes morally questionable when you know that 1 in 1000 is not guilty, compared to today where you can say "I think everyone who is in jail is guilty".
How about we make the forensic science we have actually affordable to use. It doesn't matter how great it is if the 3 or 4 labs in the state break the bank to use or are way backed up.

comment_text: Looking forward to turning 80 and becoming a master criminal

I will be starting grad school in the fall in forensic DNA analysis. Fast DNA has the potential to be a game changer in the field, but it has deep flaws in its current implementation. It's designed only to be used in known samples, such as those collected from buccal (cheek) swabs. Some agencies with the machines use them for analyzing crime scene evidence, which is often a mixture of different individuals. There's also concern that police will collect DNA from everyone they arrest or deem suspicious, just to see if they can be matched elsewhere. Not exactly great for the idea of civil liberties.

Check out more here: https://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/21/science/dna-crime-gene-technology.html

You start off by stating that fingerprints can be used to identify whether a person has touched an object.

This is false, or at least, unproven.

Fingerprints are believed to be unique, and there's good biological reasons why they should be, but the ability of human forensic techs to actually discern a match as uniquely pegged to one person as they regularly assert under oath has never been demonstrated in a peer recited study. There are similar gaps in most kinds of forensic "science."

Please do not take the assertions of people whose jobs depend on them being right at their word without proof when the life or freedom of others hangs in the balance.

Our forensic teams are radically underfunded. New procedures are great, but we can barely get what we have funded. The labs you see on tv do not exist. Or if they do, they are not the norm.

Or identify family members: resolve identities of soldiers killed in war to return bodies to their families. And also identifying parts of dismembered bodies to make sure the right body parts got together. There are families who feel it extremely important to recover all remains possible.

Or exhuming mass graves to piece together people's bodies and identifying them and thus piece together personal histories with the identities of the people.

The older (but also recent) art of creating the face of a person from their skull remains can benefit from the C-T and other imaging scans to produce copies of skulls that could then be 3-D printed for the face reproduction. Kind of like a modern version of Madam Tussaud's wax museum.

Indeed, when C-T scans were newer, King Tut's corpse was subjected to such a scan, and it revealed numerous things about him, one of which was a parasite in his ear.

In Louisville, KY there resides a mummy that was brought from Egypt, whose identity and gender was unknown. This mummy survived two different disasters (including the 1937 flood, when it was found floating on the flood waters downtown).
It rested a while in the Downtown Main Library, and when the Science Center was created, it found a permanent home there.

This mummy was scanned and found to be a young woman who was a maid of some sort, according to the markings on the sarcophagus. (I might be wrong about her occupation.)

These DNA and other identifying techniques could help us understand what went before and give future generations a record of our lives for them to study.

Maybe it could help us understand the degradation caused by radiation and also old - age genetic factors like telomere production and preservation.
